metadata.sermon_start_end: The wonders of the Old Testament are so great that it is hard to know where to begin enumerating them. One way to begin would be to identify the cast of characters. The people of the Old Testament come in several sizes. Towering over the others are the colossi [...] the way of the Son of David was prepared by adulterers like David and clever opportunists like Abigail, people like you and me, but people who have been given, in spite of themselves, a glimpse of what it means to know, to love, and to serve the Lord — and, in the process, to discover their true selves. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on 1 Samuel 25, but it treats the text primarily as a 'masterpiece of narrative art' or a character study rather than a unique, current, proclamatory word. It fails Dekker's test of finding what is in this passage that can be found NOWHERE else; instead, it reduces the text to general lessons about courage and gender equality.
quotes: These characters are striking and memorable enough to be routinely included in Bible story books.
Abigail emerges from the pages of Scripture as a person in her own right, a strong, self-possessed individual with guts and imagination.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the unique theological necessity of this specific encounter for the history of revelation, rather than treating Abigail as a psychological archetype for 'strong women'.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates literary familiarity but lacks the rigorous linguistic and historical-theological depth Dekker demands. There is no mention of Hebrew nuances, and the 'protection racket' comment remains at the level of modern comparison rather than deep religious-historical exegesis of Israel's kingship.
quotes: One commentator says that David depended on what might be called today a 'protection racket.'
The King James Version says that Abigail was 'a woman of good understanding...'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond 'Bible story book' descriptions into the specific covenantal tensions of the Davidic monarchy and the linguistic significance of Nabal's name (folly).

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely general and moralistic. It drifts into 'politically correct' cultural debates rather than concrete spiritual application for the congregation's specific life. It offers general truths which Dekker explicitly forbids.
quotes: No one can do everything, but everyone can do something.
The Biblical narratives live today because they transcend references to specific social customs.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Replace general moralisms ('everyone can do something') with concrete applications regarding how the hearer is currently 'bound in the bundle of the living' or facing their own 'Nabal-like' folly.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a chronological narrative path. While it avoids a strict 'first half exegesis, second half application' split, it functions more as a running commentary with occasional 'asides' to the audience rather than drawing the hearer into the text's movement.
quotes: And this is true of you and me also, so that we share our very essence with the people of the Bible.
Many of you will recognize this as a forerunner of the most powerful sort of enabling exhortation...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Stop treating the text as a 'stage' to look at; instead, use the text to 'expound' the hearer's current reality directly through the Word.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: While the sermon mentions 'sinful' and 'mortal' man, the sense of 'misery' is soft—focused on 'idiosyncrasies' rather than radical lostness before God. Redemption is present but borders on 'psychological help' or 'enabling' rather than the radical grace Dekker envisions.
quotes: They are human, mortal, sinful, prideful, idiosyncratic, quirky, each of them unique and unforgettable.
Abigail is 'wording' him into a new frame of mind... this as a forerunner of the most powerful sort of enabling exhortation.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect; David’s bloodguilt is not just a 'hot-blooded' mistake but a theological catastrophe that Abigail prevents by God's grace.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are almost entirely absent. There is no sense of the ultimate possibility of being lost, either temporally or eternally. The sermon ends on a note of 'discovering true selves,' which is the opposite of the gravity Dekker requires regarding the narrow way to life.
quotes: The story is told as if this were the most natural thing in the world for a woman to do.
and, in the process, to discover their true selves.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher must address the reality that Nabal *was* lost and that David was on the 'broad way' to destruction through vengeance. The choice matters for eternity, not just for 'self-discovery'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon correctly identifies Christ as the telos of the Davidic line and sees Abigail's mediation as a foreshadowing of the Servant. However, it risks making Christ a 'theme' or a 'forerunner' rather than the present Lord who is the life of the hearer.
quotes: this is the Once and Future King, the son of Jesse from whose house the Messiah would some day come.
miniature foreshadowings of the coming time when the One who will be called the Son of David steps forward...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a historical endpoint (telos) but the active subject who detaches the hearer from themselves today.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2100 words, the sermon meets the 20-minute threshold. It has the 'breadth' Miskotte requires, though it fills that breadth more with narrative retelling than theological depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Use the 20+ minutes to delve into dogmatic and hermeneutical depth rather than simply retelling the story with modern adjectives.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria by prioritizing narrative charm and psychological archetypes over the specific, proclamatory Word of God. It treats the Bible as a 'story book' of 'colossi' rather than a current revelation that places the hearer before the 'two ways.' The application is largely moralistic and focuses on 'self-discovery' rather than the radical displacement of man by grace.
strengths: Adequate length (over 20 minutes) allowing for narrative development.
Clear identification of Christ as the theological goal (telos) of the Davidic narrative.
Effective use of the 'three parts' (misery, redemption, gratitude) as a background structure, even if the 'misery' is under-realized.
weaknesses: Lack of specific exegesis; relies on English translations and general literary observations.
Failure to present the 'two ways'; the sermon lacks the 'seriousness of being lost' and ends in modern self-actualization.
Application is too general, offering 'universal truths' about courage and gender rather than concrete, specific address.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about a biblical character' rather than a sermon in Dekker's strict sense. It lacks the specific 'NOWHERE else' theological focus and the gravity of the 'two ways.' It functions as high-quality religious storytelling but fails as an actualization of the Word of God.
